title: Gang of raiders jailed after footage shows them ripping out cash machines
text:
Shocking footage captured a gang stealing £250,000 by pulling cash machines out of shops and a hospital.

The five men were today jailed for a total of more than 31 years at Birmingham Crown Court after they admitted conspiracy to commit commercial burglary.

The crooks tied cargo straps around freestanding ATMs before yanking them out using vehicles with cloned number plates or wheeling them to getaway cars on trollies.

Shocking footage captures a gang stealing £250,000 by pulling cash machines out of shops and a hospital. In the first clip shown, the gang destroy the inside of a Post Office in Lichfield to drag the cash machine through it after taping over CCTV cameras on September 29

Between last March and January this year the gang carried out 11 brazen raids while attempting several others.

Footage released by West Midlands Police shows some of the men's brazen raids.

In the first clip shown, the gang destroy the inside of a Post Office in Lichfield to drag the cash machine through it after taping over CCTV cameras on September 29.

The raid on Birmingham's Queen Elizabeth Hospital is also shown in the video. The gang wheel an ATM out on a trolley

The second clip in the compilation is from March 15 last year. The gang can be seen using cutting equipment to break into a Spar supermarket in Tamworth, Staffordshire, before ripping out the cash machine.

The raid on Birmingham's Queen Elizabeth Hospital is also shown in the video. The gang wheel an ATM out on a trolley.

The gang are also seen wheeling a cash machine out of Warwick Hospital - where their faces are shown on CCTV - and ripping one out of a Spar in Chelmsley Wood.

Footage also shows security guards dodging out of the way of their van after they are disturbed at a cash and carry in Birmingham.

Ringleader Craig Matthews, who has 19 previous convictions spanning 49 offences, was sentenced to eight years and seven months (left). David Bradley, 28, of Coventry, was sentenced to five years (right)

The brazen driver of the truck even warns the guard not to not to follow them.

Finally, a clip from the raid on Ellerbeck Stores in Tamworth is shown.

Not included in the video is the raid on September 24 in which the gang cut bollards to get into Birmingham’s Cannon Hill Park, where they dragged a cash machine from the Midlands Arts Centre.

Officers discovered that the gang were casing out their target areas before returning to carry out the raid.

Ringleader Craig Matthews, who has 19 previous convictions spanning 49 offences, left his DNA on a piece of tape used to cover cameras in Lichfield.

He was also forensically linked to a registration plate on one of the vans.

Police uncovered CCTV of him examining a cash machine while unsuspecting passengers went about their business at Rugby train station.

Shane Stajsavljevic, 36, of Coventry, was jailed for seven years and two months (left). Charlie Ward, 27, of Coventry, was sentenced to five years (right)

Matthews, 42, of Edgbaston, Birmingham, was sentenced to eight years and seven months.

David Bradley, 28, of Coventry, was sentenced to five years while Kenneth Bourne, 38, of Fillongley, Warwickshire, was sentenced to six.

Kenneth Bourne, 38, of Fillongley, Warwickshire, was sentenced to six years

Shane Stajsavljevic, 36, of Coventry, was jailed for seven years and two months and Charlie Ward, 27, also of Coventry, was sentenced to five years.

West Midlands Police used CCTV, forensics and phone analysis to bring the gang down, particularly once they were forced to abandon a getaway van.

Fingerprints left on a trolley they had dumped at one crime scene helped detectives identify the crooks.

They were arrested at the beginning of this year and went on to admit conspiracy to commit commercial burglary.

Judge Heidi Kubic described their crimes as 'sophisticated burglaries' which left a trail of destruction across the West Midlands.

Detective Chief Inspector Annie Miller said: 'This was sophisticated organised crime which showed a huge amount of planning.

The gang are also seen wheeling a cash machine out of Warwick Hospital - where their faces are shown on CCTV

'While no one was hurt during the spree, the gang left a trail of destruction which left victims facing huge bills.

'Thanks to great police work, we were able to build up a detailed picture of the gang, their vehicles, reconnaissance and movements.

'We're continuing to work with the cash machine industry to help increase security to reduce the risk of them being targeted by criminals in this way in the future.'

The industry has launched a drive called Secure ATM, including sprays that identify thieves for up to five years after an attack, dyes that are sprayed on cash and kits which neutralise gas used to blow up machines.
description: Five men were today jailed for a total of more than 31 years at Birmingham Crown Court. Shocking footage released by West Midlands Police shows some of the men's brazen raids.
